In the Bag

Sep 12, 2014
1 minute read

It’s 2:04am MST and I just bought my wife the iPhone 6. She is contentedly sleeping away, of course; I told her earlier this evening that I wasn’t sure I could do it, but that I would give it a shot. That was a semi-fib; I was fairly confident all along that I could do it.1

I’m really excited for her. She has been so patient with her old2 iPhone 4S and, although excited about a future upgrade, wasn’t setting her mind on it.

I don’t tell you all this to boast, dear reader. Rather, I am reminded of several colleagues of mine who wouldn’t dare let “the wife” get a new phone before they did; at best, they would give their wives their old phones and they would get the upgrade.

I don’t dig that perspective. My wife works so hard to help me in every possible way; the very least I could do is help her get something that she’ll enjoy – it doesn’t really matter to me that I no longer have the latest iPhone in the house. I love her and want this small gesture to show how much I appreciate her and all she does.

Now off to bed.

  1. The secret? Avoid apple.com like the plague and go straight for your carrier’s website. Since I was nice and tidy about it, Verizon let me right in. ↩
  2.  Complete first world problem, I know. I don’t mean to be disingenuous or disrespectful to people around the world who have real issues; rather, from our world view, I merely have the opportunity to reflect on my wife’s simple and content perspective. ↩
